I did not, like him, attempt a critical knowledge of their dialects, for I did not contemplate making any other use of them than temporary amusement. I read merely to understand their meaning, and they well repaid my labours. Their melancholy is soothing, and their joy elevating, to a degree I never experienced in studying the authors of any other country. When you read their writings, life appears to consist in a warm sun and a garden of roses,—in the smiles and frowns of a fair enemy, and the fire that consumes your own heart. The shutting of the gates regularly at ten o'clock and the impossibility of remaining on the lake after that hour had rendered our residence within the walls of Geneva very irksome to me. I was now free. Often, after the rest of the family had retired for the night, I took the boat and passed many hours upon the water. Sometimes, with my sails set, I was carried by the wind; and sometimes, after rowing into the middle of the lake, I left the boat to pursue its own course and gave way to my own miserable reflections. I was often tempted, when all was still, to let the boat drift, watching the stars and the moonlight reflect on the water. The silence of the night was only broken by the occasional cry of an owl or the rustling of the reeds. These moments of solitude were both a relief and a torment. The solitude allowed me to reflect on my life, my choices, and the future that seemed to stretch endlessly before me. Yet, the loneliness was suffocating, and I longed for the company of others, even if it was only for a brief moment. The lake, once a source of joy and freedom, now seemed to mirror my inner turmoil. I found myself questioning the very essence of my existence, wondering if I was truly living or merely existing. The nights on the lake became a ritual, a way to escape the confines of my life, even if only for a short while. As the days passed, I realized that this escape was not a solution, but a temporary respite. The questions that plagued me during those nights remained unanswered, and the lake, with its endless expanse, seemed to hold the answers, yet I could not reach them. In the end, I knew that I had to face my life head-on, no matter how daunting the task might be. The lake, with its calm surface and hidden depths, became a symbol of the journey I was about to undertake. It was a journey of self-discovery, a journey that would test my resolve and challenge my very being. And so, with a sense of both fear and anticipation, I prepared myself for the challenges that lay ahead, knowing that the answers I sought were not to be found on the lake, but within myself.
